answer: I view academic success as the only way to escape the neighborhood, but deep down, I rely on the interpersonal relationships within the neighborhood to confirm my self-worth.
No. I often hide my true thoughts or even imitate the other person's behavior to maintain my relationship with Lila.
Elders and teachers at school. I seek authority figures' approval through academics to make up for the inferiority I feel in neighborhood life.
To become a person full of charm and decisiveness like Lila, while maintaining my own moral security.
I alleviate anxiety by imitating Lila's way of thinking or behavior, and attribute my achievements to her influence.
When Lila displays ability or attractiveness that surpasses mine, even if I am more successful academically.
A kind of "symbiotic competition": I rely on Lila for courage and direction, yet confirm my self-worth by surpassing her.
I take on the dual role of "responsible one" and "escaper": taking care of younger siblings and meeting parents' expectations, while attempting to get rid of family constraints through reading.
It is not a pure love for knowledge, but rather viewing academics as the only controllable way to prove that I am better than Lila.
Nino represents the ideal male image of the "civilized world" to me; my admiration for him is actually a yearning to escape life in the neighborhood.
Shifting from complete dependence on Lila to trying to establish an independent self-identity, but still unable to get rid of the comparison with Lila.

In childhood, I feared it but accepted it as the norm of life; after adolescence, I gradually tried to evade violence using civilized rules (such as academics), but I was still awed by it deep inside.
When Lila deviates from my life trajectory (such as dropping out of school, contacting men), I feel abandoned and lost.
When I gain recognition in academics, and Lila temporarily does not show overwhelming superiority.
Publicly betray Lila. Even if jealous or angry, I maintain superficial loyalty.
I believe money is the foundation of dignity, but I am unwilling to obtain money through violent means like the Solara brothers.
I habitually play the "passive recipient," confirming my own value through men's attention, but inwardly despising their shallowness.
I strive to meet their expectations in exchange for care and recognition, and view this recognition as capital to resist family pressure.
Eager to integrate into the neighborhood to gain a sense of belonging, yet urgently wanting to escape it to achieve social class mobility.
Continue to move upward through education, but constantly look back at the relationship with Lila, using it as a frame of reference for self-positioning.
To surpass Lila and escape the neighborhood, proving my independent value.
Being slighted by Lila or having my achievements ignored, which shakes my self-identity.
Withdrawal and compromise, prioritizing the maintenance of superficial harmony to avoid violence.
Acquiring knowledge and cultural capital to completely get rid of my background environment.
Lila; her existence defines my direction of effort and self-assessment.
Tell myself there are still opportunities, or focus on Lila's limitations to balance it out.
Whether he can lead me into a broader, more civilized world, rather than providing security.
Solitude, used for studying and escaping the social pressure of the neighborhood.
No, personal development always comes first; friendship often gives way to self-improvement.
Someone like my mother: physically disabled, mentally numb, and trapped in the family.
Lila, she can always make me feel inadequate and anxious.
By achieving higher success to prove myself, rather than direct confrontation.
Being accepted and recognized by the intellectual class, not material wealth.
Spiritual understanding and resonance, an emotional connection transcending the physical.
Prioritize personal dreams and fulfill only minimal family responsibilities to avoid conflict.
It is a potential shackle unless it helps me escape the neighborhood.
A dependency relationship seeking redemption and authoritative recognition, viewing them as a ladder.
When Lila shows ability surpassing mine or gains attention.
Regard them as backward, violent, and fatalistic, needing to be critiqued and transcended through knowledge.
Longing for independence and autonomy, yet relying heavily on external recognition to define myself.
Ensuring I can completely detach from my original class and enter a more orderly, decent world.
Relying on her spiritual strength while feeling a hidden guilt and fear because I am living better.
Whether the other person can consolidate or enhance my social status and cultural capital.
Being slighted intellectually or morally by the class I aspire to.
Using systematic learning, writing, or imitating the words and deeds of the upper class to establish rational order.
Obtaining an ultimate, unshakable "legitimacy," proving that I belong to a better world.
I will strategically obey the party that brings me higher social capital or better aligns with my self-improvement goals, and alienate or simplify the association with the other party.
A safe haven and final destination built on reason, knowledge, and decency, symbolizing the fruits of my struggle.
In front of the Airota family, I must play the role of a successfully reshaped, decent intellectual woman.
When my achievements are denied by the authority of the target class, I am instantly beaten back to the original form of the "porter's daughter."
Never return to the lifestyle of the old neighborhood in Naples, which symbolizes failure and chaos.
Writing is the purification, beautification, and reconstruction of chaotic reality to conform to literary rules and protect oneself.
The tension between the devotion to a rational, stable marriage and the passion and old desires represented by Nino.
Proficiently mastering and using a set of elegant, complex language (academic or social rhetoric).
An anxiety mixed with disgust, pity, and unbreakable bonds; she is the source I desperately want to get rid of.
Longing to be recognized and desired by him, thereby proving that I have defeated Lila and possess a charm surpassing the past.
The contrast between my life trajectory and Lila's. Her downfall sets off my success; her tenacity reflects my vanity.
Tendency to choose men who can lead me in intellect or status, and incorporating the relationship into my personal improvement plan.
Becoming mediocre, with marriage and career stagnating, eventually becoming no different from the women in the world I once escaped.
Constructing and solidifying a narrative of life for a glamorous "Elena Greco" dominated entirely by myself, permanently burying the past of "Lenu".
Insisting on realizing personal value and independence through writing and self-expression.
My own emotional and spiritual needs.
Pursuing a life full of passion and intellectual resonance, transcending traditional marriage and motherhood.
Maintaining the relationship with Nino, continuing my writing career, and maintaining personal autonomy.
The conflict between moral guilt as a mother and emotional satisfaction as a lover.
In front of Lila.
In front of my mother-in-law Adele.
Nino's nostalgia for or concealment regarding his wife's family.
A psychological pattern of both dependence and resistance.
An intertwining of guilt and a sense of alienation.
More towards private emotion.
From escape to return, reflecting my ambivalent psychology of shifting from pursuing external recognition to accepting my own roots.
Building an image of a modern woman who is independent, clear-headed, and dares to break through constraints.
Compensation psychology and self-proving psychology.
The "incompleteness" of Nino in the relationship, that is, he wants me but is unwilling to completely leave his wife's family.
I view cheating as a pursuit of true love and self-realization to alleviate moral anxiety.
To be understood and witnessed, especially by Lila.
The opinion of the intellectual class and cultural elite.
Seeking double salvation from men in terms of intellect and emotion.
Realizing that I cannot coordinate multiple roles and can only endure the pain of being split.
